segments.text: Seven-year-old Kyron disappeared from Portland, Oregon. The second grader lived with his father, stepmother, and baby sister. Kyron was last seen by his stepmother after she walked him inside the school to drop off a project for the school science fair. But Kyron never made it to his first class.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: The first his family knew of his disappearance was when he failed to arrive home on the school bus. And Gibbs, I know that you've talked about this on a number of podcasts, me kind of looking out the window when my daughters were younger, seeing them get off the bus. And then I would follow them until they made it to the front door. I made sure that they got inside.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: If one of my girls failed to get off the bus, I'm thinking about it right now. The feeling that I would have in the pit of my stomach wondering what's going on. And actually, I've had that feeling before. I remember one time my youngest had to stay at school for something after school. Right. And everybody forgot to tell me about it. Oh, man.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I was freaking out. I called my wife on the phone. Obviously she quickly told me what it was. So my anxiety level came down. But in that first instant, those first couple of minutes, I was panic stricken. Sure. Unbearable panic.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: The case of the young missing boy resulted in the largest criminal investigation in Oregon history. Every resource available was invested in finding out what happened to Kyron with local and state police, along with the FBI combining their efforts in an attempt to locate him.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Not long after Kyron disappeared, the focus turned to his stepmother. She was the last person said to have seen him, but there was nothing directly linking her to his disappearance. And the investigation lost momentum. As time passed, it surfaced that Kyron's stepmother had allegedly put out a contract.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: on Kyron's father in the months before Kyron disappeared. This shocking development wasn't the only thing keeping the story in the headlines. Kyron's mother initiated legal proceedings against his stepmother, claiming that she was responsible for his disappearance. But even this failed to yield any information about Kyron's whereabouts.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Further suspicions were raised, possibly implicating one of Kyron's stepmother's friends in the case. And kids, we're going to get into all of this, right, as we dive deeper into this episode. But Kyron Horman remains missing to this day. Dedicated investigators are committed to finding out what happened to him. His parents hold out hope that he's still alive, despite the lack of significant breakthroughs in recent years.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So big case, a tough case. Yeah. I think always tough when you're, when you're talking about a young child, but I will say this is a case that people really cling to, right? They get fascinated by, you know, some of the details. It has led to a lot of speculation about, you know, just who all is involved in his disappearance. And it continues, right?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: To this day, Kyron Horman was born on September 9th, 2002 in Portland to his parents, Kane and Desiree. He was an only child. By the time of Kyron's birth, his parents' relationship had broken down.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: and divorce proceedings were already underway. At this time, Kane was already dating someone new, 32-year-old substitute teacher Terry Moulton, who already had an eight-year-old son, James, from her first marriage.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: According to the Williamette Week, Kane and Desiree agreed to have a shared custody arrangement for Kyron from the time that he was born. In 2004, Desiree required intensive medical treatment for kidney failure.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And given the fact that she would be traveling to Canada to receive life-saving treatment, the couple agreed that Kane would have sole custody of Kyra. When Desiree returned to the U.S., she continued to be heavily involved in Kyra's life. In April 2007, Kane and Terry got married.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And in December of the following year, the couple had a daughter named Kiera. Kyron had started school at Skyline Elementary in a rural area in Northwest Portland, about two miles from the Horman home. Terry was very involved in Kyron's upbringing.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: She volunteered at a school. She took him to swimming lessons with his stepbrother and baby sister. In February, 2010, Terry's son, James moved out of the home and lived with Terry's parents after an argument between mother and son. So there's a lot going on here. There is.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And I do think we need to unpack a little bit of it. Kyron's parents' marriage was essentially over for all intents and purposes by the time he was born. Yeah, exactly. segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And so, you know, she's traveling to another country to get this life-saving treatment. And Kyron's father has sole custody, which means that Terry is playing a very big role. A huge role. Not only stepmother, but really along with Kane, you know, kind of raising Kyron. Yeah. Because unfortunately his mom just couldn't be there all that much.

segments.text: Yeah, you got a lot of family dynamics going on here. Sure. And then, you know, Terry's son from her first marriage moves out, lives with her parents because they can't get along. Yeah.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: But on this day, he had a project with him that he had to drop off at the school science fair before his classes started. And I remember those days. To school and dropped off. It just had to be done. I remember-

segments.text: The search for Kyron continued for 10 days and included Portland Mountain Rescue. It also included the National Guard. But less than two weeks after his disappearance, it was scaled back. CNN reported on law enforcement's announcement that the case was being upgraded from a missing person to a criminal investigation.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: There was an appeal for video footage of traffic on several roads in the Portland area near the vicinity of the school. Police divers also searched the waters off the banks of the Multnomah Channel north of the Sauvy Island Bridge on Sauvy Island, but didn't provide any information as to why they were focusing on this area.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So there's a couple of things here, Gibbs. Less than two weeks after Kyron disappeared, they scaled back what appeared to be a pretty massive search effort. Again, that type of massive search effort cannot continue indefinitely. It just can't. No, it's too costly.

segments.text: Yes, costly from a law enforcement perspective, but also you have a lot of volunteers who can't spend month after month after month. They volunteered their time, but a lot of people can only do that for so long. And then you have resources like mountain rescue, the national guard. Okay. There are other things that they need to be doing.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Yeah. More searches somewhere else. Sure. So all of this has to be extremely tough on the family. Not only is Kyron missing, but then you're seeing the efforts kind of dwindle as the days go by. That's tough.
